title: John Cho suffers on-set knee injury requiring Cowboy Bebop filming to stop for up to NINE MONTHS
text:
Cowboy Bebop will stop filming for seven to nine months on account of John Cho's on-set knee injury, which has required him to have surgery.

The 47-year-old actor was in New Zealand shooting the Netflix show when he was hurt and had to travel back to Los Angeles to be operated on.

He will also undergo a great deal of physical rehab, and once more details are known about his prognosis, the production schedule will be reset, Deadline reports.

Accident: Cowboy Bebop will stop filming for seven to nine months on account of John Cho's on-set knee injury, which has required him to have surgery

Filming only started last week on Cowboy Bebop, which is a live-action adaptation of a 1990s Japanese anime series about bounty hunters in space.

John posted an Instagram upload as news broke of his injury, assuring fans that he would be all right and back in the saddle soon.

'"Water can flow or it can crash," - Bruce Lee,' captioned John. 'Thanks for all the well wishes everyone. Gonna be back and flowing in no time!'

Staying positive: John posted an Instagram upload as news broke of his injury, assuring fans that he would be all right and back in the saddle soon

Netflix is apparently determined not to find another actor and prepared to delay filming in order to keep John in the lead role of bounty hunter Spike Spiegel.

The original animated series takes place in 2071 and consists of 26 episodes. Netflix has ordered a 10-episode premiere season of the live-action remake.

Cowboy Bebop was lauded by critics after it burst onto the scene in Japan in 1998, and it was then introduced by American audiences by Adult Swim in 2001.

Premise: Filming only started last week on Cowboy Bebop, which is a live-action adaptation of a 1990s Japanese anime series about bounty hunters in space

Along with John, the cast of the new Cowboy Bebop includes The Boys actor Alex Hassell and Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom actress Daniella Pineda.

Revenge alumna Elena Satine and The Deuce actor Mustafa Shakir will also be featuring in the live-action version of the show.

John's role was originally played in the animated version by Koichi Yamadera, who has done Japanese dubbing for such Disney roles as Donald Duck and the Beast.
